body.name: An Island at War: A gripping and emotional World War Two historical novel

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank
productInformation.value: #177,789 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #212 in Sibling Fiction #640 in Historical World War II Fiction #1,327 in War Fiction (Kindle Store)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2024
reviews.reviewText: What a marvelous story. The characters were really well written and became so real to the reader. This story shows. that the enemy, no how disgusting the the leadership was, there are those who remain a decent human.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars An eye opener to the struggles of the Channel Islands in WW2
reviews.reviewText: One of the best things about Historical fiction novels is sitting back in shock. There are so many issues that are not touched on in history classes or textbooks. If they are mentioned, they are usually just a quick mention.An Island at War gives insight into the struggles of the islanders stuck in the middle between England and Germany during WWII. They were soon occupied by the Germans for the duration of the war. The author went into detail sharing the struggles, the hopes, the frustrations and the fears of the islanders.My only complaint is that the ending left me hanging. Is Gerard alive? What does Rosie think of the Island when she returns? Will Hans come back for Estelle in a few years and be able to have a relationship? It does go to show how invested I became in the story. I hope you will become invested as well

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Something was always happening so it was hard to put down.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I read the first three chapters wondering if it would be too difficult to bear knowing the history. Yet I continued and just could not stop reading. An excellent description, bringing history to life.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great story - helped me visualize what they went through.
reviews.reviewText: This story took place at the time that my Mom was 17 years old, and living in England. I recall the stories I used to hear as a young boy about having to go into the bomb sheltersas "Jerry" was coming over, and then coming out to discover the damage. This really brought those stories to life.The writing was a pleasure to read. It flowed off the page wonderfully. It was a really good story about life on the island and the difficulty of separation caused by the war. I enjoyed the book a lot.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Island at War, good but not great
reviews.reviewText: I find it fascinating and moving to read about how the people on the Channel Islands survived the occupation. This book touches on it but omits most of the gory details and descriptions. I feel like the hardest subject matter was glossed over throughout the book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 16, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Life on the island
reviews.reviewText: A very moving story of life on the tiny island during the Nazi occupation, the strength of the main character and the hardships of all. Also the love that can be found in difficult situations. Excellent read

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great story and good history
reviews.reviewText: This book was exciting, well written, interesting history, but no gory details.
It was a great read and enjoy the author. Would recommend it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 19, 2024
reviews.reviewText: A lovely historic book. Really enjoyed it. Will order other books by this author.
Def enjoyed this WW2 readVery believable.... well researchedClass this with many other great WW2 historical dramatic readsHad hard time to " turn off the light" and go to bed😊

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on July 9, 2021
reviews.reviewText: I really enjoyed reading this story of life in Jersey during the German occupation. I loved the main characters, especially Estelle, her Gran and Hans, and in particular was looking forward to the ending as Estelle’s friendship with Captain Hans Bauer developed (I couldn’t wait!) ... and here comes the ‘but’! How disappointing the end of the book was! It just fell totally flat at the very end as if the author had suddenly run out of ideas and didn’t know how to end the story. Did Gerard and Paul return safely from the war? Don’t know! Did Hans ever come back to visit Jersey after the war? Don’t know! Did Estelle eventually settle down with Gerard? Don’t know! It was such a let-down how abruptly the book finished with the comment “They were free, finally”. We all knew that anyway, as the islanders were celebrating in the square at the time with the British soldiers raising the Union Flag! I would have loved a proper ending detailing what happened to the characters just after the war, having invested a few days of my life embroiled in their lives. If a sequel was published, I would gladly buy it just to find out.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on September 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: Makes the historical facts more personal and relatable - good read
reviews.reviewText: I was lucky enough to be reading this book whilst I was on holiday / visiting Jersey for the first time and visited the War Tunnels, the docks at St Helier and the museum plus did several walks along the North coast of the island and the green lanes. I therefore could relate to places mentioned in the book. It also makes the historical facts more personal and relateable. As the book had a family at it's centre it brought the impact of the war on the different generations into focus. It also highlighted the human side of both the islanders and the Germans - showing the good and bad of both. A good read.
